segments.text: This is August 7, 1987.
I'm Bob Cornish, and I'm interviewing Wolfgang Roessler in his office at Texas A&M Department of Urban and Regional Planning.
I'd like to begin, Wolf, by asking you about your studies in planning, where you did your work in academia.
and your degrees, and then how you came to be in the United States.
By airplane.
Thanks.
Well, I earned my doctorate at the University of Hesse, Marburg, in economics and sociology with an emphasis on urban planning.
notably transportation planning.
In fact, my dissertation was one of the first computer modeling attempts of that period and had to do with measuring the cost effectiveness of commuting versus resettlement.
That was the era when there were
large numbers of homeless people all over Europe, all over Western Europe, millions of them.
There was a very current issue.
What do you do with these people?

They mostly lived helter-skelter, and wherever there was some quarters, there were camps thrown up overnight by the various government and military, government forces, and people lived in little towns, and they
If I work in nearby communities, it was just a survival kind of thing.
What year was that?
That was the whole period from 1946 to 1948.
And during that period, this quite coincidentally, I became interested in that issue of resettlement versus leaving people where they are and strengthening commuting facilities.
a number of applied research projects I was involved in.
So that's how all this fitted together.
And then I did receive a scholarship from the University of Wisconsin through the U.S. military government in the state of Hessen and Professor Howard Becker, who is a noted sociologist, period.
So I went to
Madison, Wisconsin, on that, and that's where I met Walter Blucher on a trip to Chicago.
And Walter Blucher said, why don't you stay here?
You could make a contribution, particularly with the skills that you have in computer applications to transportation.
Why should you do that?
And one thing led to another.
There were, at that time, two jobs open in the United States.
One was in Louisville, Kentucky, and the other one in Kansas City.
I like Kansas City, and so I went there.
And my assignment, first assignment was to develop a comprehensive analysis of future travel demand patterns that was to become the basis of the urban freeway system for Kansas City.
And then, of course, leading to all the other related considerations of economic and
social policy and land use planning policy at the local level and whatnot.
And before I knew it, I was an active member in the old American Institute of Planners.
And that was a very pleasant experience.
It was a very small congenial group of highly competent people.
in contrast to what the mass organizations later deteriorated into.
Anyway, it was a very pleasant experience, and it helped me shape my own career objectives.
When did you become associated with Ladislas Segal?
Oh, that was much later.
Much later.
After the first Kansas City tour, I became planning director in Palm Springs.
And that was a very interesting experience.
What year was that?
That was 53.
And then I went with Segal in 58.
And in between I had done another study for Kansas City that there was a huge annexation north of the Missouri River and in Jackson County.
And then eventually went with him.
I met him along the way at meetings.
through some committee work in the AIP.
So one day he offered me a job and I joined his firm.
And then you moved to Cincinnati.
I moved to Cincinnati.
From Palm Springs.
And that was actually professionally the experience that led me
into the consulting business for the rest of my career.
And we worked all over the place.
And of course, he was very much avant-garde in the plumbing profession.
We had a lot of common interests.
And it was easy for us to work together.
And so I did dozens of master plans on a lot of interesting studies in San Francisco and Seattle.
around Washington, D.C., in specialized areas.
Like, for instance, this building envelope business that we were, again, applying in the San Antonio River works that came out of that period.
Segal taught me how to do that in connection with the project in Seattle, and then another one in Cincinnati, sort of his thing.
It had to be done very painstakingly.
He was not, anyhow, a typical planner in the sense that the majority of the people in the profession defined themselves in practice.
He was always determined to solve problems.
And he said, somebody comes to you, and he says, I want to comprehend the plan.
But mostly, that's really nonsense.
They really don't know what they want.
But somewhere, there is a problem.
And then it's your opportunity, when you identify this, to teach them how to relate all of these different aspects to each other.
And that then makes it truly comprehensive rather than going through a ritual of five or six steps that so typically show up in all these planning reports.
Well, I could relate to that.
And so I think we're a very successful team.
However, for some reason,
Nazi Sieger wasn't interested in getting into the major transportation studies of that period, and I was interested in that at the time.
So when Ruben Bergendorff asked if I would join their company as a planning director... For the transcriber, how do you spell Bergendorff?
B-E-R-G-E-N-D-O-F-F.
It's a Swedish name.
I took over that whole business, and I did consider a number of huge transportation studies.
I had, at times, 150 people working for me all over the world, literally, in this country, in Australia, and you know, wherever you are.
So, that was fine, but somewhere along the way, I had hoped to
spent the last several years of my career productively in an academic environment.
And I had several offers and didn't really do much about it.
And eventually, Jack Williams, who was president of Texas A&M at the time, offered me this position here as head of this department.
I wasn't too interested in this because I told him I didn't really care to have
more administrative responsibilities, but as it turned out, I spent two-thirds of my time at A&M with administrative details, which hopefully will come to an end sooner or later.
So I came here.
Why did Jack Williams want you to come to A&M?
Jack Williams was dismayed.
He said he wasn't... he had lots of problems with the College of Architecture, and he didn't feel that the
Department of Urban and Regional Planning, as it was called, really had the strengths that he thought it should have, and it didn't perform to his satisfaction.
There had been apparently a lot of unpleasant experiences with faculty and administrators and whatever.
It's not worth even remembering, but it was a situation that had given the

department and the college had, in part two, a reputation of being odd, being not worth it, dealing with things that they shouldn't be concerned with, having more individual members, more concerned with headline hunting and politics and teaching, producing quality education, at least in the views of the

Since he knew my general attitude and what I thought of what I might do with planning education, and it has to have a meaningful linkage to reality and so on, and has to produce people who can, in fact, perform effectively immediately upon completion of their academic work,
He said, I should try that.
We'll give that department one more chance.
If you can do something with it, then everybody will be happy.
If not, no harm done.
I came in 1975, that summer.
So Virgil had been interim department head for the spring and the summer.
Virgil was the interim department head.
And what I found was preposterous.
financial administrative mess, that they were defunding totally inadequate.
And the first thing I did is I had a meeting with the then vice president for academic affairs, John Calhoun, and told him that, and asked him one role, dean of faculties.
And I said, I spent more money in my little plumbing firm in one week than I did here to spend the whole year.
And it's ridiculous.
They agreed, and they asked Dean Reed why it was, and he had no meaningful answer except that he didn't really care, I think.
However, through intervention by the vice president, that was corrected for the academic year that was about to get underway, and so at least I had some funds for running of the office.
and supporting financially some of the graduate students through assistance shows.
And that helped the morale considerably.
The students were marvelous.
They were extremely supportive.
I met with them.
I told them what I had in mind and that some things had to be changed.
There had to be a basis established, a discipline, operation.

and we had to operate just like we operate in a public or private planning office and not impossible way that things were running in all directions and there was no objective no goal or any such thing and much to my surprise three members of the faculty were very opposed to any such change but with the help of the students we accomplished it anyway and uh
I don't think I want to get into that.
And it was pathetic, really pathetic.
They all eventually joined the more productive part of the faculty.
And gradually, we managed to establish something that resembled a professional unit.
It was also clear to me in 1975 that the traditional planning program was pass and no longer served a useful purpose.
There was hardly anybody who would employ people who knew nothing about how to make land use surveys and they had to learn something better than that.
And so we instituted the emphasis areas in planning.
which other schools had done successfully, and that helped us strengthen our position.
We also did another thing.
We decided that all laboratories would have to be sponsored by some outside agency so that faculty and students had the opportunity to practice their trade and remain up-to-date.
However,
I felt that we had to add some other programs to the department.
There was some discussion about an undergraduate program, but the university administration was adverse to that, and I could get very little support for any kind of undergraduate program.
But when I raised the question of a PhD, I was immediately given a great deal of support
Vice President's office, and they said, yes, that's the kind of thing we want in academic orientation.
And there was a doctoral program called the Doctor of Environmental Design, which is a low-grade professional program.
And I thought that that should be discontinued.
And the faculty agreed with that.
And so we simply changed the requirements for that degree

to the PhD requirements in the traditional sense, and eventually asked the administration and the state board, the Texas College and University Board, to change the title to PhD in Urban Regional Science.
That has helped us tremendously, and we were able to build, over the years, a fairly effective doctoral program on a tutorial basis.
The products of that program had by now reached substantial, significant positions in academia and industry and government, and so they proved a point.
That was the first Ph.D. in the college.
It was the first Ph.D. in the college, and it was logical.
It had a broad enough basis.
procedures that had originally been initiated by the University of Wisconsin by Ratcliffe in his program on land economics, and later expanded substantially into what is now called regional science.
So we used that, but we added another dimension.
Since the regional science and land economic programs
highly quantitative, almost entirely quantitative.
We felt we needed another dimension.
We simply called it urban science, which is broad and doesn't commit us to anything.
So the degree can go into either direction.
And it has done this very well.
We've had some discussions.
Some dissertations have dealt with policy issues.
Some have dealt with law.
And some have dealt with, many have dealt
typical traditional regional science issues, highly quantitative.
So that went on for a while.
And by the early 1980s, the department's enrollment had increased from the original around 30 to about 60 students.
And that was considered pretty substantial for a graduate department.
The next phase of the early 80s, 82, 83, I had a lot of health problems and resigned from the department head position, and David Pugh took over at that time.
Upon my recovery, about 60, no, I mean 84, did I say 60?
We had, again, reached the point where something needed to be done to invigorate the master's level programs.
And for various reasons and developments around the country, it seemed appropriate

to take a look at one of our emphasis areas and that was the emphasis on land development and it had become so popular with the students that the then provost gordon eaton suggested that we give this planning emphasis its own identity and so we came up with the master science and land development i managed it through the
university and state minefields and got it eventually approved.
That didn't take very long, did it?
No, it was a record time.
In eight months, I think, we got the whole thing through.
Eight months.
And, yeah, I was... We had a real fine relationship during that period, the faculty, with the provost.
He was interested in our work, and he pretty much let us do anything we wanted to that was reasonable.
And so that was accomplished.
And with that, then, the departmental enrollment increased substantially and is now generally between 90 and a little over 100 students.
And at first, perhaps unexpected, the enrollment in the MS program was at the expense of the MUP program.
David Pugh and I knew that this would find its level, and we weren't overly concerned about it.
Others were, but we were right.
It found its balance, and for the last two years, the two master's programs have had about the same enrollment.
Another interesting experience from this was that, since there is commonality, first semester students can...

change to the other program if they want to after they get to know things a little better and again there seems to be no trend of going from one to the other it seems some people just prefer the traditional city planning others prefer the entrepreneurial land development but as many stand now the doctor program has about 40 percent of the enrollment
and the two master's programs, each about 30% of the enrollment.
That, for our present faculty, is manageable.
We couldn't manage these many students were it not for the interdisciplinary character of the MS program and the doctoral program.
Faculty in the business college and in the engineering college
Some in liberal arts are as much involved with us and with these students as our own faculty.
So my outlook for the future is that this will probably continue to remain like this with greater and greater
emphasis on the doctoral program.
You can read it in the Wall Street Journal periodically and Forbes and other magazines.
There's pressure in industry and pressure in government that higher-level management positions, not only research positions, somehow require that the candidates have a doctorate.
And that's not just in our field, it's just everywhere.

there's more demand for this and from the faculty's point of view presents all too good because there's more money in it by the same token the masters programs i think will also increase simply because of the goals of the nation and and opportunities that seem to be very plentiful we have
had no period, to my knowledge, where our students did not find jobs.
They all did.
Yes, even in this era of downturned Texas economy, there doesn't seem to be much problem.
There seems to be no problem for the planners in Texas.
There seems to be a little problem for the land development graduates,
But they have found ready acceptance in California, in Florida, in the Northeast, in Washington, D.C.
There are plenty of jobs.
In fact, people come all the way from Miami to interview here and have hired our people.
State agencies such as the Texas Real Estate Commission have recognized the degree as satisfying all of the
academic requirements for any of the licenses under their jurisdiction.
The California Real Estate Commission has also accepted that, and so we're in good standing with the major regulatory agencies.
The Urban Land Institute has recognized us in a recent article.
We were listed together with MIT and the University of Wisconsin and the University of Southern California as one of five schools that actually teach land development.
One other thing I should mention, if you know on and off, I observed this interim department head during the last three and a half years, because our department head, Sweeney, is the interim dean.
Another thing that happened about four years ago, we thought that the university needed some assistance in helping it achieve its own goals.
Well, one of its goals was clearly described by a panel in the
Texas 2000 report, or whatever they called the thing, was that Texas A&M should assume a leading role in urban affairs.
And nobody knew what to do with that.
So at that time, I just thought it might be time to get all those faculty members together who may have an urban interest.
So we organized an urban affairs faculty as a very loose association and had a bunch of meetings and came up with a program.

One of the program objectives was to establish a center for urban affairs that would be capable of contracting with anyone who wanted to render a service, and the service would be provided by all these experts from the different disciplines.
And it's worked out beautifully.
We've had the regents allowed us to do that, and we've had any number of fascinating engagements with private interests,
And with the major cities in the state, San Antonio has sort of become our undisputed headquarters for numerous activities.
And I finished in Gordon-Eccles recently the Riverwalk project.
We've been involved in all kinds of projects.
And just about anybody on the faculty who wanted to had a chance to do that.
We created professional advisory boards
one for the Master of Urban Planning, and the five members are recognized planners of the region, and we created another one for the Master of Science in Land Development Program.
It was composed of leaders in the industry.
For example, Michael Crow joined us last week as a member, and so we have...
I think being able to demonstrate to everyone that we can make a contribution, the university does not question that at all, and has supported us effectively, I think.
The profession has recognized our contribution, which has been very substantial.
In our recent accreditation visit, there were numerous statements made that without Texas A&M, there would be no Texas chapter.
And the Texas chapter depends on Texas A&M for numerous things, not only for the contributions of everyone in the faculty, but also for other short course in this matter.
I think one can't ask for more.
I would think that the state of affairs of the department is excellent at this point.
Were no longer threatened by the administration?
Not threatened by anybody.
On the contrary.
With being dismissed from the ranks of the university?
No.
No, in fact, on the contrary.
Since about 1980, I think, the university has made peace with that and said the program is very solid.
And Dr. Eaton was particularly vocal about that and pointed that out on various occasions.
Would you want to comment on the relationship of the planning
degree programs to the dean's office.
You mentioned Ray Reed, and he was relieved by Charlie Hicks.
And we had another relationship there.
And then Charlie was relieved by Don Sweeney.
And our fortunes have varied substantially, it seems, depending upon who was occupying the dean's chair.
Well, you would expect that.
It's the nature of it.
The

academic organization is simply that the university administration depends on the deans to carry out their policies, and consequently the deans have substantial power with respect to budget control, and that's really where the key issue lies.
Reed and Hicks were very weak deans who
didn't even understand their own profession.
They learned the function of a dean.
They were ineffective.
It is tragic that the presidents of the period were not interested in the College of Architecture, or they would have done something about that.
They took more the position

as long as they don't bother us over there i know they're a little bit crazy but they don't bother us we leave them alone and that was the attitude now that's no longer the case it has changed completely in fact again i would give gordon eaton credit for having changed that dramatically and you know saying i want to see the same uh recognition of that college and productivity as everywhere else the college was not as a whole productive in my judgment it was has
I can find a lot of thought with it.
And it is now, in the last three careers, I think, finally gotten to a point where, at the departmental level, efforts have been made to raise its prestige and standards.
And I think Don Sweeney, as an interim dean, has done a good job in creating
a business-like image of the college, and where they don't have the feeling anymore that this is just a group of rather strange individuals, and they wouldn't want to even do it.
They pay attention to us, and they treat us with respect.
And people who perform, who do what is expected of an academic person, are well-treated by the central administration.
That has changed completely, and we hope that with the new dean who is coming in in January, that will continue and be further strengthened.
Many of the faculty
under Ray Reed and Charlie Hicks had the feeling that urban planning was simply not understood by the Deans.
Not only did they not understand it, but they didn't really much care about it.
Well, I'll tell you what happened there.
That was true, they didn't understand Deans and understand their own world, but since I had established at Adam early on that I wasn't going to
knuckle under to these deans, and I would go to the provost, if need be, and get what I think we had to have in order to do our job.
They hated that.
They were very resentful of that.
And the moment they had an opportunity to undo what had been gained, they did.

And it wasn't until fairly recently that I found out, for instance, that the construction science department received, under Hicks, allocations for graduate assistantships in the amount of about $2,400 per capita, whereas we got $500 per capita.
It was outright fraudulent.
And it is very, really very sad that
a central administration allowed these things to be so badly mismanaged.
I think if you wanted a classic case of mismanagement, this college has ample material.
In the form of several individuals.
That was rumored for some time.
about this imbalance between the various departments under Hooke's regime, Hicks regime, but it was only a rumor circulating.
And as such, of course, it caused a lot of concern and resentment.
Well, it was even more tragic with respect to faculty compensation.
You're talking to one who suffered from it.
It was just unbelievable what was done to us.
And, well, this is past history.
The important thing, I suppose, is that the Department of Health and Regional Planning and its two
Creation Center for Urban Affairs and the Center for Historic Resources are going to be heard from in the future.
They are a major unit, a major entity of urban affairs and urban planning in the southwestern United States.
And the interesting thing is, as much as we were mistreated by our own deans, the outside world had looked upon us with great
They were awed by all the accomplishments of the individual faculty and of the students.
Our students have a tremendous reputation.
The department looks like a giant from the outside.
And I think it will be more so in the future.
I have great hopes for that.
And of course, with some of our students having reached and attained positions of prominence, that hasn't hurt us.
Henry Cisneros in San Antonio, and I'm sure
Henry Cisneros would be the next governor of the state of Texas.
And then he would appoint some of the regents, not appoint some others.
Right.
Some of your comments do recall for me the attitudes at the time during previous dean checks.
And it seemed to me and to others on the planning faculty

that the more we tried to do the more it seemed to be resented not only by the college at the college level but at the university level and i think you hit on one point earlier that when you arrived here there was a lot of sort of grandstanding and i think that the university was a bit gun-shy
of any faculty doing anything that would involve publicity, and that they might have overreacted to faculty trying to do something.

That's very true, and I think that's probably why the administrations that I served under and I had an easy time of working together because, you know, in the consulting business, you learn very quickly, and it becomes second nature to
Stay in the background.
Your client takes the credit.
Your client is the great hero, and you do the work.
And I adopted and continued the same policy, and it worked very well for us because nobody criticized us for grandstanding effect.
Now I hear the other side, they say, you ought to move your own horn a little bit more.
You ought to tell the world what you're doing.
I'd rather have it this way than the other way around.

Well, now that we have three solid degree programs in the department, and we have created two university-wide centers, and we have other accolades such as David Pugh being president-elect of the Texas chapter of APA, and I've been on the board of trustees of the
Society for American City and Regional Planning History, and so forth.
All of these things seem to be coming into being in a very solid way.
How do you take a look at the future with a new dean coming on board and Don Sweeney returning to the department as our permanent department head in January?
What do you foresee for the future?
You pointed out a very important thing, that topology has played a leading role in the professions at the national level.
Don Sweeney works at the Health Association.
I'm sure you know also the director of the American Clown Association.
I served as the director of the, what do you call it, Educators Association of Collegiate Schools of Clowning.
So we've all done these things.
Now we have kind of
regrouped, decided that you can't do everything.
Everybody can't do everything.
So Chewy and David Pugh continue to concentrate on the American Planning Association, American Institute of Certified Planners.
You do the newly created Society of Planning Historians.
Sweeney does the public health thing.
I deal with the Irwin Manor Institute.
So we all do different things.
I also deal with the Institute of Traffic Engineers, and then I'm a fellow in that institute.
And so is Virgil Stover.
We've covered that.
So that I think our, as a faculty, our reputation is truly national.
And we continue to broaden this.
The only way you can redo this is through a lot of publication.
And I think our faculty, hopefully, will learn that.
That is extremely critical.
We have added a research dimension to the faculty with Nabil Safat, who has outstanding credentials.

is very much involved with the National Science Foundation on econometric and transportation theory issues and so we continue to do that next year when you retire we will undoubtedly attempt to find a planner with substantial theoretical credentials as well similar to Nabil and
thereby round out the capacity of the department.
I would also look for the two centers to develop some staffs over the next two years on a permanent basis so that, let's say, by the end of this decade, by the time that I expect to retire,

we will have created not only a strong academic unit with an enrollment of somewhere between 120 and 150 persons but we also have created two adequately staffed research centers and outreach centers we will do more on an international basis we are very much in demand
Fulbright grants are available to us.
The AID has approached us again for assistance.
And so we're involved with a number of foreign universities.
And again, our former students are now in leading positions with some of these universities.
So it is a network.
And I would expect us to do more of this, to network internationally
and both in the academic teaching area and in the research area.
We were recently approached by an Australian group to, Michael McCarthy, to assist them in developing a land development program.
So I think all of these outreach activities will improve our
prestige and strengths, and with that, also give us an entirely different position in the college and in the university.
I have every reason to believe that Michael McCarthy will be very supportive of that, affecting conversations I had with him and in exchange of correspondence.

continues to express that and also express his admiration in a way that we were able to do all these things with such limited means and i think that he is accustomed to much more adequate and much more liberal budgets he would press for that and so i think that the future of the department will be
very, very good.
It sends to the national scene a return to common sense and urban affairs after the Reagan fiascos.
I think the public is ready for solid contributions from the planning profession
and to a large extent under the leadership of the major universities, where the intellectual capacity is to deal with the issues that are sometimes seemingly insurmountable.
I think we had a backlash in the early Reagan years of anti-climbing, anti-everything, and that's long gone.
You can see it in very conservative regions like Texas.
Climbing is alive and very well, and the public says,
plan and don't just waste our money with ridiculous schemes.
There's this whole issue of the aging population, including you and me, that is an area that we haven't even
effectively addressed at all.
And it's a major planning consideration, policy planning and physical facilities and all the rest of it.
So I think that the opportunities are tremendous.
In transportation, we'll be getting into the high-speed train era, as the Europeans have.
You can't build any more airports.
There's no room.
How many airplanes can you have in the sky at any one time?
And they're all in trouble right now.
They're all in trouble.
And so I think that technology
new modes in transportation, new public policy, new social policy issues that simply are not wishful thinking or response to fantasies, but response to enormous needs.
When I read in the Wall Street Journal that it costs something like $25,000 to accommodate someone in an acceptable retirement home,
I mean, where is all this going to lead to?
That's where I think planners come in.
And I think having laid the foundation in our period, you and I, with three very solid programs that all relate to that and interrelate, the future of this planning program will be tremendous.
I think it will be a major function on campus and also a place where people will
compete for appointments because it would be very desirable to be a part of this entity.
Not that it hasn't always been.
I think that that is probably our greatest strength.
I think we've all felt great satisfaction working together, and we're very proud of each other.
You mentioned one point regarding
The Reagan administration and so forth.
And it seems to me that both Nixon and Reagan have succeeded eventually.
It's resulted in removing the planning responsibility from HUD.
And all they're concentrating on now is housing.
And affordable housing, I think, is the current buzzword.
It seems to me that there has to be some federal agency that has some interest in planning as such around the country.
And that's got to come back again in some format.
And if it doesn't at the federal level, I think that the universities, as you've entered, have a responsibility.
to play that they haven't had before.
And there's a vacuum that somebody's going to fill.
Yeah, the universities are the only place where you can really create the intellectual and research base for all these activities.
It has to be somewhere in the executive branch, a central urban planning office, whatever it's called.
HUD
So my prejudice is they have never really done anything worthwhile since its inception.
It was well intended, but it's been a disaster.
And then the developments in the housing market, financial developments have undermined it to the point where it's almost really useless.
It has to be...
